"Division 6—Native title functions of prescribed bodies corporate and holding of native title in trust

PARA.EMPHASIS: Determinations by NNTT and Federal Court

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the NNTT or the Federal Court proposes to make an approved determination of native title; and
(b)the determination is that native title exists at the time of making the determination;

the NNTT or the Federal Court must, at the same time as it makes the determination, make the determinations in section 53A (which deals with holding the native title on trust) and 53B (which deals with non-trust functions of prescribed bodies corporate).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Determination whether native title to be held in trust

PARA.TAB: "53A.(1) One of the determinations that the NNTT or the Federal Court must make is whether the native title is to be held in trust, and, if so, by whom.
"(2) The NNTT or the Federal Court is to take the following steps in making the determination:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)first, it must request a representative of the persons it proposes to include in the determination of native title as the native title holders (the `common law holders') to indicate whether the common law holders intend to have the native title held in trust by:

PARA.TAB: (i)nominating, in writing given to the NNTT or the Federal Court within a specified period, a prescribed body corporate to be trustee of the native title; and
(ii)including with the nomination the written consent of the body corporate; and

PROCTEXT.PARA: (b)secondly, if the common law holders give the nomination within the period, the NNTT or the Federal Court must determine that the prescribed body corporate is to hold the rights and interests from time to time comprising the native title in trust for the common law holders; and

(c)thirdly, if the common law holders do not give the nomination within the period, the NNTT or the Federal Court must determine that the rights and interests are to be held by the common law holders.

PARA.TAB: "(3) On the making of a determination under paragraph (2)(b), the prescribed body corporate holds, in accordance with the regulations, the rights and interests from time to time comprising the native title in trust for the common law holders.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Holding of native title to be as prescribed

PARA.TAB: "(4) The regulations may also make provision in respect of the following matters relating to the holding in trust of the native title rights and interests:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the functions to be performed by the body corporate;
(b)the nature of any consultation with, or other role for, the common law holders;
(c)the circumstances in which the rights and interests may be surrendered, transferred or otherwise dealt with;
(d)the determination of any other matter by the NNTT or the Federal Court;
(e)the termination of the trust or replacement of the trustee where the common law holders wish the trust to be terminated or the trustee to be replaced;
(f)any other matter.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Determination of prescribed body corporate etc.

PARA.TAB: "53B.(1) If the determination under section 53A is that the native title rights and interests are to be held in trust by a prescribed body corporate, the prescribed body corporate, after becoming a registered native title body corporate (see the definition of that expression in section 238), must also perform:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)any other functions given to it as a registered native title body corporate under particular provisions of this Act; and
(b)any functions given to it as a registered native title body corporate under the regulations (see section 53C).

PARA.TAB: "(2) If the determination under section 53A is not as mentioned in subsection (1) of this section, the NNTT or the Federal Court must take the following steps in determining which prescribed body corporate is, after becoming a registered native title body corporate, to perform the functions mentioned in subsection (3):

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)first, it must request a representative of the common law holders to nominate, in writing given to the NNTT or the Federal Court within a specified period, a prescribed body corporate for the purpose;
(b)secondly, if a prescribed body corporate is nominated in accordance with the request, the NNTT or the Federal Court must determine that the body is to perform the functions;

(c)thirdly, if no prescribed body corporate is nominated in accordance with the request, the NNTT or the Federal Court must, in accordance with the regulations, determine which prescribed body is to perform the functions.

PARA.TAB: "(3) After becoming a registered native title body corporate, the body must perform:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)any functions given to it as a registered native title body corporate under particular provisions of this Act; and
(b)any functions given to it under the regulations (see section 53C).

PARA.TAB: "53C. The regulations may make provision for a registered native title body corporate to do all or any of the following:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)if it does not hold the native title on trust under section 53A—to act as agent or representative of the common law holders in respect of matters relating to the native title;
(b)to perform in a specified way any functions in relation to the native title given to it under other provisions of this Act;
(c)to hold on trust, or perform functions in relation to, compensation under this Act for acts affecting the native title;
(d)to consult with, and act in accordance with the directions of, the common law holders in performing any of their functions;
(e)if it does not hold the native title on trust to enter into agreements in relation to the native title that are binding on the common law holders, if:

PARA.TAB: (i)the common law holders have been consulted about, and have authorised, the agreements; and
(ii)the agreements have been made in accordance with processes set out in the regulations;

PROCTEXT.PARA: (f)to perform any other functions in relation to the native title.

PARA.TAB: "53D. The regulations may prescribe the kinds of bodies corporate that may be determined under section 53A or 53B in either or both of the following ways:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)by providing that bodies corporate may be established and operated for the purpose in a specified way;
(b)by providing that the bodies corporate may be those that have been or may be established by other laws of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory.

PARA.TAB: "53E. The regulations may make provision for the replacement of a prescribed body corporate by another prescribed body corporate at the initiation of the common law holders.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate that the last thing this parliament does on this last sitting day of the International Year for the World's Indigenous People is to pass this Native Title Bill. It is appropriate that, in the passing of it, this parliament this day will do more, and will have done more, to return to the Aboriginal people of this country their own soil.

PARA.TAB: Mr Chairman, just on a year ago I launched the International Year for the World's Indigenous People at Redfern. During that speech I raised the opportunity presented by the High Court's decision in the Mabo case and reiterated my view that this presented a huge opportunity for Australia; that here we had a basis for reconciliation formerly denied us but that we had to seize the opportunity and build a body of social, property and administrative law around the High Court decision which would then provide a basis in land for indigenous Australians to participate more fully in this society, and to do something real and material about a genuine basis of reconciliation.

As it happens the government campaigned on this issue, among others, in the election campaign. It won the election and then it set about systematically developing the lines of logic and principle that ought to lie behind a comprehensive piece of social and property legislation like this when it is brought to the parliament. It has probably been the most worked over piece of legislation in the 11-year history of the Labor government, and it saw the devotion of more ministerial and bureaucratic time than any other piece of legislation in the period. Also there was a round of consultations with the various stakeholders and interested parties—most particularly the Aboriginal people, for whom the bill was designed, but also the states, the farmers and graziers, the mining industry, and all of the other groups that have an interest in Aboriginal policy and who are interested in development.

The bill has sought to meet the twin goals of justice for Aboriginal people and the establishment of a workable system of land management. This the bill does. It gives to Aboriginal people the right to have claims for native title heard and awarded in a stream of the Federal Court of Australia and in the state supreme courts, and it gives to the states and state institutions the power to make economic decisions over native title land. We believe that these mechanisms will serve the country well in allowing the great rural and mining industries of this country to grow and prosper while at the same time maintaining a position of harmony with the interests of Aboriginal people.

The lesson of Mabo is that we should never underestimate our capacities for solving our problems. We should take this legislation to be a victory for all Australians and the Australian nation because it is a profound event. It should mark a new spirit of faith and optimism in Australia that something of this complexity can in fact be mastered and agreed.

The difference between the opposition and the Labor government is on this subject, as it has always been—Mabo has made this clear: the opposition represents the politics of pessimism and despair; we say there is every reason to be optimistic. The opposition presumes ill will among Australians; we presume goodwill. The opposition can only talk of national disaster; we talk of national success. The opposition believes in property rights only for some; we believe in property rights for all, including indigenous Australians.

One might be tempted to dwell on the abysmal role that the opposition has played in this debate, for never has a political opposition exhibited less vision, less principle or less faith in the people of Australia and their democratic institutions. Never has an opposition shown less leadership or been so badly led. But this is not a day for political retribution. I dare say, Mr Chairman, in due course, the Australian people will make their judgment on the opposition's dismal role in this great national achievement, as the Liberal Party, no doubt, will soon make its judgment on the dismal role of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

This is a day to celebrate the powerful, creative forces which conceived and brought to fruition this historic legislation. I mean those people and their organisations who imagined there might be a solution to the problem and who had the strength of will, the determination to succeed, the intelligence to negotiate and to argue the case, and the good feelings towards one another to make sure their hopes were realised. This was displayed across the political system and the social fabric of the country—bar the opposition. So this is very much a day for indigenous Australians to celebrate and, indeed, for us all to celebrate the strength of the Aboriginal people and the capacity of our democracy.
The bill puts an end to the great lie of terra nullius, the notion—

TALK.START.PARA: —The High Court did that.
—Order!

—You were going to wipe out native title. That is how much you were going to put in to end the lie. The beginning is, as I said, a basis for social justice and reconciliation. In the bill the government has made provision for the acquiring of pastoral leases and their conversion to native title. The government will be introducing a social justice package next year amongst which we will have a land acquisition fund, the purpose of which will be to allow Aboriginal people to buy pastoral leases and to convert them into a native title. Of course, that land will attach all the negotiating rights which obtain with native title land under the bill. This will mean that Aboriginal people will not only simply acquire a pastoral lease which is no more than simply a pastoral lease but underneath that pastoral lease will then sit a native title.

PARA.TAB: In this way we believe that those Aboriginal people dispossessed of their land, who would not have the opportunity of benefits under this legislation or under the High Court's Mabo decision, will be able to secure land by purchase which will then have a native title and then have all the negotiating rights attached to it—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the miners, the leaseholders.

—The Leader of the National Party talks about the mining industry. The mining industry will have no problems with this legislation. There is a process of negotiation with a relatively tight timetabling. In the event that people cannot agree, that is, the proponents of economic proposals and Aboriginal people, they will be heard by an arbitral tribunal. That tribunal will decide whether development will proceed or not. In the event that a state government or a state minister believes a certain development should proceed, that development can proceed with a very clear override provision by states, for states, in the legislation. But, of course, that is for development. In terms of the validation of past titles, the bill validates the titles issued after the Racial Discrimination Act was introduced in 1975 and makes clear that those titles issued between 1975 and 1992 are valid.

PARA.TAB: There have been a number of major amendments to the bill that do not change the structure or the principles of the bill but are worth mentioning. There is an amendment which clarifies the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act as far as the bill is concerned. That amendment adds a new clause 6A to the bill to make it clear that validation for past acts can proceed free from any possibility of conflict with the RDA, but making it clear that the future processes set out in the bill are subject to the RDA. This amendment retains the certainty the government always required—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the one you said was a shame. You said it was a disgrace to introduce such an amendment.
—Your spoiling strategy came to nothing, did it not? It was another failure. Fightback a failure; Mabo a failure. Two out of two is your track record.
—Order!

—In response to recommendations by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the government proposed amendments to provide for a parliamentary joint committee to monitor and review the operations of this bill. This is a unique piece of legislation and a formal monitoring mechanism seems appropriate. There was also an amendment to provide for the Aboriginal Social Justice Commissioner to provide a yearly report on the operations of the act and its effect on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. There were also amendments to provide for the renewal of existing valid leases. These amendments were not the government's preferred option for dealing with this issue but, in the absence of any support from the opposition, there was a need for a compromise. The amendments, we believe, are workable.

PARA.TAB: After negotiations with the minor parties and Aboriginal representatives, the government agreed to sponsor a package of amendments relating to bodies corporate under which the original provisions would have held native title on behalf of the native title holders. As a result of the amendments, the native title holders can now choose whether or not a body corporate will hold the rights on their behalf. There will still be a body corporate which will act as a representative body for native title holders.

The bill went to the Senate with very clear principles and very clear logic to it. In the course of the Senate debate the government has accepted the amendments I mentioned and some other amendments which we think strengthen the bill—a consequence of the whole debate which saw, firstly, the presentation of a discussion paper by the government just after mid-year. Then consultations followed with the Aboriginal community and with the various stakeholders and the states saw the presentation of a draft bill. The draft bill was then circulated for comment. We took the comments on board from the states, the mining industry, the farming and grazing communities and the National Farmers Federation. We took those to cabinet and amended the bill as we thought it should be and then produced a bill.

The first writing of the drafts of the bill was again circulated. We had feedback on those drafts and some of that was incorporated in the legislation. We went on to produce the bill and introduced it into this parliament. In the course of its passing this House and the Senate there were further discussions and negotiations, and these amendments are the result.

It is probably the most negotiated bill that has been through the parliament—certainly in the last 10 years—and the consultations have been broader than has been the case for any other piece of legislation. There has been a very long debate in the parliament on the bill. As a consequence, we think now we are at the point where the bill with the amendments needs to be agreed to by the House of Representatives, having been agreed to by the Senate.

I wind up by again putting on the record my thanks to those people who participated generously in the debate. I want to again, as I have done publicly, reiterate my appreciation to Ms Lois O'Donoghue, the Chairperson of ATSIC, for agreeing to negotiate with the government, to lead her community and to lead ATSIC towards the negotiation table. It was that primary negotiation within which the interests of Aboriginal people were considered. Subsequently, that brought in wider support in the Aboriginal community. As a consequence, I think now most members of the Aboriginal community have confidence in the legislation.

I also thank those members of the states—the Premiers and members of the state bureaucracy—who worked to try to improve the legislation to provide a basis for economic development which could actually work and proceed. I thank those Premiers who stuck with the legislation, most obviously Wayne Goss from Queensland because he refused to sign the coalition letter the other day. But, even though he did, Jeff Kennett—

TALK.START.PARA: —And what's he doing now?

—I know what Richard Court is doing now—he is rethinking his position. As a consequence, Mr Kennett supported the legislation at a critical time. I would like to place on record my appreciation of the role of Mr Farley of the National Farmers Federation who, with principle and goodwill, represented his constituency's interests, which, of course, was not done by those in the coalition—the National Party and what have you—who claim the same interests.

PARA.TAB: I particularly thank my ministerial colleagues who participated in the ministerial work: the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner); the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch); the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker); my colleague the Minister for Resources (Mr Lee); the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean); Senator McMullan; the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon); and others who were involved in the discussion from time to time.

I thank the officers of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, particularly the leader of the bureaucratic group, Mr Sandy Hollway, Mr Mike Dillon and their officers. I thank also Mr Simon Balderstone on my personal staff, who maintained a continuing oversight of the policy. I also thank the officers of the Attorney-General's Department, particularly Mr Robert Orr, who stuck with the debate on this legislation under great personal pressure, as did all of them, over a very long period of time. I particularly thank the members of the Labor caucus who had the vision and the faith to persist with the bill and to see justice done for Aboriginal people.

I also place on record my appreciation for the valiant job Senator Gareth Evans did in the Senate in arguing the intellectual case against such provocation by the coalition for over 40 hours of debate. His triumph in the intellectual argument ensured that the bill withstood any scrutiny. All of these people were key to the bill succeeding. Again, let me reiterate that the Aboriginal community, the so-called `A team'—Ms Lois O'Donoghue and her group, Mr Noel Pearson, Mr David Ross and others—were a key to keeping Aboriginal support and arguing the amendments through.

I had hoped that the opposition would support the legislation; that after 18 months it would have come to a position on Mabo. In the end, the opposition's position was that it did not want to give Aboriginal people an inherent right to land. In the end, the opposition openly lined up with and supported the Western Australian government which sought to extinguish native title.

The Leader of the Opposition went around the Aboriginal communities of this country to listen to what they said. He saw them but he did not listen and, as a consequence, he came up not with a policy but with simply an obstructionist view that the government's legislation ought to fail and deserved no support. The Liberal Party and the National Party have lost a great opportunity to return to the mainstream of Australian life and Australian society. That is their decision. But there has been a total absence of leadership on this, a marginalising of the coalition and a total failure on its part to alter the course of the legislation or to have any real impact on the debate.

The coalition vested everything in the notion that native title ought to be extinguished and that state parliaments ought to be able to hand out a statutory title conferred on Aboriginal people at the whim and caprice of ministers. In other words, the coalition decided to wipe out any proprietary right to inherent title. In the end, the duplicity of the coalition is highlighted by the fact that it believes in the rule of law except when the High Court says something it does not like. The coalition claims that it believes in private property—except the private property rights of native people, of Aboriginal people.

This humbug and hypocrisy in the debate will condemn the opposition for not standing and supporting the rule of law when, in this case, the highest court in the land, the most supreme of our courts, made a decision. Later, we will hear the Leader of the Opposition say that he supported the High Court decision; but he immediately wanted to wipe it out. He supported native title but then wanted to extinguish it. He also wanted to deny Aboriginal people proprietary title, to give them no proprietary rights but simply a set of rights which were not to be defined and which could be tested only in a dispute. And the coalition is talking about the amount of land which will be alienated from Australia, as if native title in some way will remove the land and the pastoralists from this continent. It is a pity that there was no leadership by the opposition and that, as a consequence, the bill did not enjoy bipartisan support.

The great joy is that the bill succeeded. We on this side of the chamber rejoice in its sentiments and what it will do to empower Aboriginal people and to give them a stake in Australian life and Australian society which they have not until this time generally had. I commend the amendments and the bill to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said yesterday, this is a day of shame for Australia that will haunt the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his government every hour of every day between now and the next election. The Prime Minister stood up here and put his hand over his heart, claiming to represent the interests of Australians in general and Aboriginal Australians in particular. He then set out to exploit the politics of this issue through the essence of his comments this morning. It was a classic piece of Keating hypocrisy.

PARA.TAB: The best way to encapsulate what has been done with this piece of legislation is to recognise that it is simply a deal and, as deals go—and this takes some doing—this is the new low watermark of deal making in this country. It was a deal stitched up between a weak Prime Minister, some Aboriginal leaders, one pastoralist and the minority parties in the Senate. In doing that deal, the Prime Minister sold out all Australians and the interests of all Australians. It was nothing more than a deal, stitched together for political ends. It reveals how far the Prime Minister will capitulate to the left wing of his own party in order to save his political hide.

One of the most offensive elements of this debate is this tendency on the part of the government, particularly the Prime Minister, to argue the case that if people do not support this bill they are bigots, racists or un-Australian—that if people do not support this bill they do not have a commitment to justice, dignity and self-respect for the Aboriginal people. That should be seen for what it is: total humbug and total hypocrisy.

He has tried to equate support for this bill with a commitment to justice, dignity and self-respect for the Aboriginal people, which it is not. We are absolutely committed to justice for Aboriginal people. We are absolutely committed to the dignity of the Aboriginal people. We are absolutely committed to self-respect for the Aboriginal people; but we can dissociate ourselves from this monstrous piece of legislation.

We are proud to stand up here on behalf of all Australians and dissociate ourselves from this piece of legislation. We will have this debate every day, as I say, between now and the next election. The fact is that he has sold out the interests of the people of Australia, including Aboriginal Australians, for the sake of this tawdry deal. And that is what will go down in history as a result of this process. It is not a watershed, it is not a turning point for the benefit of all Australians but a turning point to the detriment of all Australians.

There was a very simple proposition put before us by the High Court's decision, and that was to recognise native title. The challenge was to codify or deal with native title in a way that was fair not only to Aboriginal Australians but to our great mining and pastoral industries and to all other Australians as well. It was a very simple issue. He did not need to take the decision he has taken and to build the paraphernalia he has built of tribunals, registrars and assessors that goes way beyond the intent of the High Court decision.

This bill could easily have satisfied that basic requirement, but it failed to do so. The essence, therefore, of our opposition to this bill is that it clearly fails in its central purpose. It does not ensure that all Australians are treated equally under the law. It does not address the real concerns and the aspirations of Aboriginal and Islander people—things like their health, their living conditions and their education—or the issue of the recognition of their culture and heritage.

The bill does not guarantee security of title or remove the uncertainty that has arisen. Farmers are still going to end up in court, for example. Its massive complexity will ensure that investment will be discouraged, jobs will be lost and national development projects will be held up—to the detriment of all Australians. By comparison, the opposition put up a very simple and direct proposition which had three essential pillars: firstly, to recognise the High Court decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —You extinguished native title.

—No, we did not extinguish native title. This is part of the myth that you have been propagating. The fact is that we recognise the existence of native title, but we leave it to the states, as it is under the constitution, to take primary responsibility for land management in Australia. We recognise native title, but we leave it to the states to handle the issue of native title in their separate domains, subject to the existence of the Racial Discrimination Act. That is a simple, direct, just and workable proposition.
—You washed your hands on Aboriginal people.

—We are not going to be part of any massive power grab—more power for Keating and more power for Canberra—at the expense of the states, which is what this legislation is. This legislation is a massive attempt to undermine an essential element of our constitution and our federal system of government, that land management is primarily a state responsibility.

PARA.TAB: This is all part of the Keating agenda to undermine the constitution and to undermine the structure of the federal system. It is all part of more power for Keating at the expense of the states. We are prepared to stand up for the constitution and ensure that the states continue to maintain that responsibility for land management in Australia. But they have to do that under two constraints: firstly, they have to do that by recognising native title and, secondly, they have to do that subject to the Racial Discrimination Act.

So what the Prime Minister was just standing up here saying about us wanting to extinguish native title is wrong. All we want to do is ensure that we have a simple, direct, just and workable response to this particular decision of the High Court, and that is what is possible—not one that goes dramatically beyond the High Court decision, not one that raises a whole lot of other issues and transfers a whole lot of other rights that were not envisaged in the original High Court decision, but simply a structure that will work, that will be fair, that will be just and that will not have the adverse economic and social consequences that this legislation will have.

Our case against this legislation is very clear. We are going to vote against it basically for one reason; that is, it is bad legislation. It is bad legislation for a number of reasons. It is bad legislation because it goes way beyond the High Court decision; it is bad legislation because it creates enormous complexity, delay, uncertainty and division in Australian society; it is bad legislation because it takes a mistaken view of the root cause of Aboriginal and Islander disadvantage; it is bad legislation because without good reason it constrains the future opportunities for national development to the detriment of all Australians and creates future financial liabilities, the scale of which nobody can predict. So in simple terms—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.
—Billions, you said, Frank—billions of dollars.
—Yes, that is right. You are asking the people of Australia to sign off on a blank cheque which the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker) at the table admits could run into billions of dollars.
—Rubbish.

—You said billions of dollars; you cannot run away from it. We have no idea of the extent of the compensation payable under this legislation; we have no idea of the size of the land acquisition fund; we have no idea of the size and the commitment of the social justice package which is running into billions of dollars—not to mention the lost jobs, the lost investment and the lost exports involving billions of dollars which are going to flow from this piece of legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has done a deal to save his political hide. He has done a deal and he has capitulated to the left wing of his party. After the budget he was persona non grata in his party; this guy was dead, he was sacrificed. The honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) was sacrificed and the Prime Minister was put on notice—`Deliver to the Left or you won't remain in a job'. What you have got is a total capitulation to the left wing of the ALP and a deal stitched up between the Prime Minister, the left wing of his party, a pastoral leader and the minority parities in the Senate—all to the detriment of most Australians.

The Prime Minister has sold out the miners; he has ignored the sentiment of state leaders. There was a statement made this week by all but one state leader opposed to this legislation, seeking delay. He has sold out the miners, he has sold out the farmers, he has sold out the state leaders and he has sold out all other Australians who are going to be significantly worse off as a result of this legislation going through this parliament. This is indeed a day of shame for Australia. (Extension of time granted).

The Prime Minister can laugh, but he is going to go down in history as the most divisive Prime Minister this country has ever seen. He has lost sight of what matters in Australia, he has lost sight of what is right in Australia and he has lost sight of what is fair to Australians. He has consciously set out to divide this nation for his own political ends.

Whatever happened to the idea of one nation? He was the man who ran on one nation. He has set out to divide this nation for his own political ends. He has done it on the basis of a tawdry deal between himself and a few on the Left of his party, the minority parties in the Senate and one farming leader—he has sold out everybody else. He has consciously set out to divide this nation for his own political ends. He has no respect for the things that matter to average Australians; he has no respect for the rights and responsibilities of individual Australians; he does not care less about the extent to which he sacrifices what matters to the great bulk of Australians for his own political ends.

As he once said to me after the last election, `You have got to understand one thing, John; this is just a game to me—I'll say or do anything. It is just a game to me'. That is right. He said that it is a game. He stands up here and put his hand over his heart and says he is standing up for Aboriginal people when he is in fact selling out the interests of Aboriginal people. He is selling out the interests of all other Australians as well with a piece of legislation that is totally unnecessary as a response to the High Court decision.

He has built a structure which he knows is designed in part to grab power from the states, to take away from the states what is otherwise their constitutional responsibility—namely, land management—and he has set out to pull that power to himself. He has put his own ego and his own values ahead of the best interests of the people of Australia.

He has basically said to the states, `If you don't play by my rules then you don't play at all. If you don't play by my rules, I'm going to take the power of land management off you and take control of land management in your state'. He should look some time at the magnitude of the land that is subject to dispute as a result of the High Court decision and the necessity to put in place a fair and workable system.

The bottom line of his approach is that his system is not workable. It will result in massive delay in major development projects right around Australia and could well be the fundamental turning point for the mining industry. He has already heard major miners in this country saying that they will move their exploration activity offshore. One major miner has already told me that, as a result of this legislation, he does not believe he will see another new mine open in Australia. The bottom line for average Australians is lost jobs, lost investment and lost export opportunities. He is sacrificing the interests of all Australians for his own tawdry political ends. He has done a deal which is the low watermark of deal doing in this country, when he consciously and knowingly set out to divide Australia for his own political ends at the expense of the interests of all Australians.

Mr Chairman, the coalition is proud of the position we have taken on this bill on behalf of the people of Australia. We will continue to give voice to the concern, anger and disillusionment of Australians over a Prime Minister who has so visibly lost touch. As we made the point last week, he has now embraced something of an imperial or regal lifestyle which is totally divorced from what those true believers he claims to represent can identify with. He stands up in this place and elsewhere in Australia, puts his hand over his heart, says he stands by Chifley and other Labor leaders of the past, mouths the rhetoric of Chifley and then goes out and lives a lifestyle and pursues interests that are totally divorced from the lifestyle and interests of the people he claims to represent, and people out there see this Mabo legislation as part of that pattern.

What on earth is he on about? He has lost control. He is selling out to minority interests at the expense of the rest of us and dividing the nation for his own political ends. How can this man be so out of touch? How can he be so out of touch with the interests and aspirations of the people of Australia? Perhaps most disturbing is that a lot of Aboriginal people woke up this morning knowing that they will get nothing directly out of this. For example, nothing will happen to remove the disadvantage in their education; nothing will come out of this to remove the disadvantage in their mortality rates or illiteracy rates, or in their lack of housing opportunities or lack of job opportunities.

What we cannot understand is that somebody who claims to represent the interests of Aboriginal Australians really has no concept of what their concerns and interests are. They are appalled at the extent of the disadvantage they now suffer relative to other Australians. They cannot understand why their educational opportunities are so much more restricted than they are for other Australians. They cannot understand why their job opportunities are so much more restricted, or why it is so much harder for their kids to get a job or to get an education, or why their mortality rates are so far out of line with the rest of Australia. They cannot understand why the Prime Minister does not seem to understand the basic needs and aspirations of Aboriginal people, let alone the rest of Australia.

Mr Chairman, the coalition is totally opposed to this piece of legislation. It is bad legislation. It will prove to be a disaster for Australia. It goes way beyond the High Court. It introduces inequities into the Australian system. It consciously sets out to divide the Australian nation and there is only one thing you can do with bad legislation and that is throw it out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the government has accepted the amendments in relation to the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill. The first matter relates to the mature age allowance. In my view the amendments are quite sensible because they ensure that people who receive a mature age allowance and undertake part-time work will be able, if they lose that work, to go back on the mature age allowance rather than having to receive other forms of benefit that are available to the unemployed.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the compensation recovery arrangements, the opposition has agreed to the majority of the provisions that the government has sought to enact. But we have moved to delete from the bill those compensation measures which deal with the question of excluding from benefits those who receive a compensation payment to replace lost income or future income earning capacity. We wanted to do so because the particular measure, as it is intended to operate, will characterise all compensation payments as 50 per cent economic loss related. The impact of such a provision would be that a beneficiary might

SPEECH.PARA: suffer a significant preclusion period as a result of the compensation being characterised as 50 per cent for economic loss.

PARA.TAB: That could mean, for instance, that an invalid or age pensioner who was involved in a motor vehicle accident and received a small compensation payment for pain and suffering or out of pocket medical expenses would have part of that payment characterised as 50 per cent economic loss related. There would be a preclusion period for that person being able then to obtain social security benefit.

While there are discretionary provisions in the existing law which allow the government to make a decision to grant a person an ex gratia payment, the fact is that the way in which those provisions have been construed—this has been confirmed by the courts—has meant that a person would not be able to get the discretion exercised that is available unless there were new guidelines.

The government tells us that the guidelines are very complex and difficult to draft. I do not believe it is beyond the wit of parliamentary counsel to come up with appropriate guidelines for advising officers on the exercise of a discretion. If the government is given time, it will come up with an appropriate set of guidelines for implementation of the discretion. So, for that reason, we have deleted all of the provisions at this time; but, if the government brings back fresh provisions along with appropriate guidelines for administering discretion, obviously we will be prepared to look at this measure again.

In relation to the movement of 16-year-olds from Austudy to family payments, the opposition took the view that this measure would have quite a significant impact, particularly on families, because the measure was designed to save the government money, which it can do only by reducing the support available. It does this by applying different assets and income tests. Our view is that the measure would disadvantage families, particularly rural families. We opposed it and we are pleased that the other parties, the Australian Democrats in particular, joined us in opposing that particular measure.

The final matter relates to data matching. The government sought removal of the sunset clause that brought data matching to an end. We would have been prepared to look at these provisions more realistically if the government had been able to produce evidence that data matching was achieving the outcomes originally foreshadowed. The government expected savings of the order of $300 million from data matching. In the end, in net terms, a mere $3 million saving has been demonstrated in the most recent reports of the Auditor-General who has examined this matter.

At this time it is appropriate to deal with the data matching by ensuring that the sunset clause presently in place—which would have seen the provisions expire on 22 January 1994—remains in place but with the substitution of a new sunset date of 22 January 1996. This is an appropriate response which gives the government flexibility in future years to move in relation to this matter. But it ensures continuing reports on the adequacy of the data matching regime and it leaves open the option of having the sunset clause operate if it is demonstrated that the data matching has not realised the objectives set for it.

All governments should take appropriate action to minimise death and injury arising from the accidental or intentional use of firearms by:

The power to regulate the acquisition and possession of firearms lies with the States and Territories. At the Premiers meeting on 22 December 1987 all jurisdictions, with the exception of Tasmania, requested the Australian Police Ministers Council (APMC) to give further consideration to a number of issues related to gun control. A special meeting of the APMC was held in March 1988. Although the meeting passed a number of resolutions aimed at controlling the ownership and use of firearms, progress towards achieving uniformity of approach between jurisdictions has proved difficult. It has proved impossible to achieve the broad agreement which the Commonwealth regards as essential to the effectiveness of legislation in all jurisdictions. However, the Commonwealth is committed to continuing to work through the APMC to encourage the further development of a national approach.

On 23 October 1991 the Australian Police Ministers Council adopted a set of resolutions to be used by each jurisdiction as a basis to reform guns laws across Australia. On 22 November 1991 a Meeting of Premiers and Chief Ministers decided to implement the positive steps taken by the Police Ministers at their October meeting and indicated their full support for the principles agreed to by the Police Ministers, as a guide to the reform of the gun laws.

The NSW Government acted quickly on this matter. It drew on the resolutions of the APMC, and on the recommendations of the NSW Joint Parliamentary Committee Upon Gun Law Reform, to formulate new gun laws for NSW. These new laws came into effect on 1 May 1992, within the target date of 1 July 1992 proposed by the Police Ministers.

A special booklet, entitled `New Firearms and Domestic Violence Legislation', was issued by the NSW Police Service on 27 April 1992 to inform police and the general public of the new legislation. In addition, the Police Service conducted special training courses for its officers.

Mail order firearms entering Australia are subject to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. Within Australia, however, there is no general prohibition on sending firearms through the mail. Any proposed amendments to the Australian Postal Corporation Act to restrict the carriage of firearms through the mail would require `end user certificates' to be issued by State authorities before Australia Post would dispatch firearms. In order to successfully implement this legislation the full cooperation of all jurisdictions would be required. In April 1989 the Commonwealth wrote to the States to seek their views on such a scheme, and although some jurisdictions were in favour of it, others opposed it on both Constitutional and practical grounds.
